review_title: Be very careful accepting a job United Healthcare...
job_title: IT Project Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: I worked with a lot of great people and I found my work to be challenging and fulfilling. The benefits were ok, the pay was average.
cons:
United Healthcare will do everything they can to legally screw you over when you leave the company. There are several states that have recently made it legal for a company NOT to pay you vacation pay once you give your notice, United Healthcare will definitely take advantage of that. I worked with my manager to give them three weeks of notice (at his request) in order to finish up work I had assigned to me. My reward for this loyalty and dedication? UHG screwed me out of several thousand dollars I had earned in unused vacation time. In calls to their benefits office I was told, 'we are well within our legal rights to not payout PTO when you resign.' 

I am baffled as to why a multi-billion dollar company would be so petty but, they are so be very careful when taking a job with UHG. Absolutely shady.

review_title: If you’re desperate go for it, if not...RUN
pros: There aren’t any, the insurance isn’t even as great as it should be for you to be working for a damn insurance company.
cons: Micromanaged to death even when your performance track record doesn’t call for it. job constantly changing so much so that it’s no longer the job you originally took, additional tasks added but pay doesn’t increase at the same rate and they will intentionally try to get you to hire prospective employees for lower than the market average. No perks in management or as a salary employee, They’ll require you to work over or you will need to to keep up with the impossible workload but if you need a half day they want you to use your time! Constantly threatened and bullied with write ups even when there is no basis for it. Penalized if you treat the job like church and state and only maintain a professional relationship with colleagues (no spreading your personal business, not going to have drinks with your team). Asked to be honest and then black balled and overlooked for advancement when you are. I can’t thank God enough for getting me away from that soul sucking job into something that better aligned with my health. It literally was making me physically sick, high blood pressure, constant migraines. I’ve never been to the doctor so much in my life trying to figure out what was happening to my body but it was stress! How horrible is it to work for an insurance company that supposedly promotes health and wellbeing when the job and the leadership running it create and promote unnecessary stress and chaos that will lead to you being unhealthy physically and mentally. My new job has completely increased my wellbeing, they trust and appreciate my contributions and i have better pay, perks and essentially less work! It’s possible! Do not work for wellmed unless you’re desperate. There is a reason why their turnover rate is so high.

pros:
-Depending on which part of the business, the coworkers can be pleasant
-WFH policy is generally very open, but depends on the manager attitude
-Salary is good, but like mentioned in other reviews, gets easily outpaced by the market
-Generally, everyone makes an effort to listen to issues brought up by employees
-PTO offering
-If you land on a good team with directors that can manage their leaders well, it makes a whole world of positive difference
cons:
-Disregard for process, lots of "urgent" requests that result in rushed work that is difficult to take pride in accomplishing
-Uninspired leadership lacks diversity of perspective, very self-congratulatory leader culture filled with people that don't actually know how to do anything but meet with each other and present what they met about to their teams
-If you tell leaders "No" in any way, be prepared to search for a new job
-Don't expect support from anyone; employees are left to figure everything out on their own
-Lack of clarity on all work projects, particularly when requests come in directly from leadership
-Benefit offerings are not great, considering this is a health insurance company. 
-Work/life balance is extremely up and down. You'll be told often they don't want you working nights and weekends, and then they will expect work be done on nights and weekends. And while on PTO.
-LOTS of meetings where nothing gets accomplished other than scheduling another meeting
-They've spent years talking about increasing career development opportunities, and there has been very little improvement for all the talk. If you want to pursue a track in leadership, you will need to move to another company - UnitedHealth appears focused on hiring leaders from outside industries
-Regular major administrative restructuring leads to yearly layoffs, job security is not a sure thing. And company culture only gets worse with every shake up. 
-Political bias is now RAMPANT in all areas. You will get treated differently if you reveal too much about your personal life and opinions.
-Reviews, raises and bonuses appear arbitrary and not tied, in reality, to performance

pros: Pros? You've just got hired with one of the biggest Fortune 10 companies! It took me 102 times to apply within a year to land this job. I did not give up, apparently. PTO is great! For new hires, you get 18 days + 5 holiday days and you have the option to buy up to 40 hours additional PTO time. If you have a good boss, work-life balance is great. Work from home was a huge one for me and this can happen as long as you show leadership that you meet your metrics and are study with production. Benefits is more like 80/20. Nowadays, I think that is a good deal. You would think the logic is since you're working for a big company, it should be at least 100% coverage, as it only make sense, right? But, in simple terms, 80/20 would be the best description. 401K and stock discount price at 15% is another great benefit here. The salary here is competitive. Be sure that you are happy with your pay as a new hire and don't settle for the minimum pay on the application.
cons: Like any other big fortune companies out there, this is a corporation setting. There is no true CON at this company unless if you are not a hard worker. Everything else will find its own place. Patience is key.

review_title: United Healthcare is a place for personal growth
job_title: Project Manager in Minetonka Mls, MN
pros: United Healthcare allowed me opportunities to move from one job position to another. I received tons of on the job training. In 12 years I had 4 promotions. The culture being pushed by senior leadership is that you are welcome to explore and take advantage of learning opportunities to get where you want to go. I did it without a 4 year degree.
cons: Here' the thing...the medical benefits are awful. The lowest deductible is $1,700.00 per member. I don't know what the family deductible is. Dental and vision are okay and no too pricey. Job security can be hit and miss. I was just laid off after 20+ years. While I can be rehired, it is up to me to post for a new job. I know that to be rehired it's not what I know, but who I know. Probably the same for most employers. Also, Sr. Management  touts that they won't tolerate harassment in the workplace, but if your manager dislikes you and makes it his or her duty to destroy your work record, there is nothing you can do. They are very pro-manager.

job_title: Senior IT Business Analyst in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Challenging.  Room to grow (if they need you to grow). They are cutting edge a many healthcare delivery technologies. Good PTO allowance.
cons:
This is a healthcare company.  The fact that a healthcare company offers such poor healthcare benefits to its employee is shameful.  Senior management should be embarrassed, but I think they’re too busy watching their stock price appreciate to notice.  
M&A has led to a hodgepodge of systems, policies and cultures.  Communication and coordination between companies/departments under the UHG umbrella is cumbersome.
Salary/raises are below average.  HR corporate policy limits raises for promotions to 10%. I applied and was offered a position TWO pay grades higher, but turned it down because I was actually going to make LESS money (losing overtime).    Seriously?  Raises have been 1.6% - 1.8%.  Note that inflation is ~2+%.  This means that each year you work at UHG you make LESS money (in real, adjusted for inflation dollars).
Talent Acquisition is also vexing.  I started as a contractor and went FTE.  When I applied for the job (that I was already doing) I got no response.  My manager at the time contacted HR. They stated I was not qualified for the position.  I repeat: an HR rep. 1500 miles away said I was not qualified to apply for the job I had been doing to the previous nine months.

review_title: Don't Work in the Call Center
job_title: Customer Service Advocate in Minnetonka, MN
pros: The best reason to work at UnitedHealth Group is the pay.
cons: Poor work life balance in the call centers. You have metrics that are hard to meet unless your cutting corners doing your job.  Internal employees have a hard time getting internal jobs, a co-worker was told she wasn't offered a second interview for a position because the process for transfer internal employees is to long and that they needed to fill the position fast. They also hire management in the call center that lack poor leadership skills. Senior management makes decision that are out of line with how the customer service department works, for example we can only work 2 hours of overtime per day (management claims they made the change for better work life balance) but some people in the call center work 4 ten hour shifts and then overtime is added to their schedules. So I ask you were is the work life balance for a person that works that shift, you could be working anywhere from 10.5-12 hours a day. Don't get me started on the culture and values, they don't exist in the call center. The company pushes compassion but will give you an occurrence if you miss a day to go volunteer, but other departments can volunteer during there normal shift. Once again call center employees are treated like SECOND CLASS CITIZENS with this company. I would recommend this company to a friend but not a job in the call center.  BEWARE!!!!!!

job_title: Medicare Risk Adjustment and Quality Consultant in Houston, TX
pros:
I've been with the company for 5.5 years and this is my 4th position. Tremendous opportunities and flexibility to move among departments and business units. I've reported to 3 directors who had shown strong leadership, communication and provided constructive criticism at times to help me move forward.  I intent to stay with the company for many years to come. 
Many pros: 
1. Telecommute.  A colleague once shared 25% of the organization employees work from home. All my positions with the company have been telecommuting.
2. Excellent ESPP  (15% discount of lower trading price at either beginning or ending of the 6-month-trading period). Maximum 10% auto debit from paychecks, managed by Fidelity.
3. Have passed my 5 year tenure and received 28 PTO days plus 8 national holidays. I started with 23 PTO days plus 8 national holidays. 
4. Decent tuition reimbursement. Finished my masters a couple of years ago and if my memory serves me right, the company reimbursed $5,500/year for non clinical programs.
cons: Just as any large organization, UHG is highly matrix and complex. It was very frustrating at the beginning of my employment with the company - being a telecommuter, lived in Houston, TX reported to NY but territory was northern CA.   Didn't know who to turn to for questions and resources. It took me a couple years and lots of research to be able to successfully perform my job.  For telecommute positions, self-started and self-motivators tend to do very well.

review_title: Great company until they coldly lay you off, and strong evidence of Ageism!
pros: Huge company with tons of opportunity (allegedly) and some business units practice very good cultural values.  Extremely strong market presence and enormous innovative advancements.
cons: A lot of smoke blowing as they tell you what an awesome employee you are and then coldly lay you off and forget about you without any effort whatsoever to place you anywhere else in a $250+ billion dollar global organization.  I had great reviews and no corrective action and out of nowhere was laid off (with severance package).  During my final week and since (my employment ended 12/2019) I've submitted well over 50 applications many of which matched my former job title verbatim and all rejected without even an interview.  I'm in my early 50's and almost positive at this point that I'm a victim of Ageism, which is unfortunately really hard to prove, but I can't come up with any other explanation since I was an existing/former employee for 3 years with 20+ years of business experience, 10 years of healthcare experience and a Master's in Health Informatics.   Many, many jobs I applied to had strong alignments with my background/skill set and I didn't even get a phone screen.   Something's not right with that and very suspicious.

job_title: Claims Adjustment Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
*Telecommute
*No micro managing 
*Benefits are descent
cons:
My department went through many changes and while I don’t think the changes themselves were bad the way they were implemented and the lack of communication made the last year frustrating. I found that some managers were great and others were the opposite, like no in between with people. There are a lot of long time employees/managers who quite frankly are either lazy or just have no drive and it makes it frustrating at times, upper management needs to clean house of employees who don’t actually do their job.
Transferring to another position is nearly impossible as an internal candidate, regardless of how high your reviews are. It’s easier to get hired on externally than promote within. Management is lacking training and they do not develop their teams. It would be wise for the company to start focusing on that before people leave the company all together. 
The biggest pitfall of telecommute positions is people don’t notice your work and it’s almost like you’re forgotten about unless you work in the office. The only people who promote within this department are people who are very aggressive or loud and it makes it miserable for the regular representatives. 
Every subject matter in our department is either very rude and abrupt or doesn’t stop talking about themselves and showboats. We need leaders that actually want to lead and do so by example, not just in performance but in social etiquettes. 
Management is not receptive to hearing feedback and takes feedback personally even if it doesn’t pertain to them but just a general criticism.

review_title: Only a number, not a person….
pros: Beautiful new office locations with lots of amenities for employees.
cons:
- Lack of communication from management - always.  I can't remember a time when honesty played a role.
- Misleading employees on the status of their jobs, and management very secretive, will not dispel rumors or the "churn".  This really turns down the environment and takes from motivation and production. 
- Zero "Human" in Human Resources, you are not treated as a person, just a number.  They will not help you with work issues that require action to be taken (i.e., sexual harassment, ethics/integrity, etc.).  Will leave you feeling violated and not valued. Plus, "HR" is outsourced to Mercer, and not even UHG employees.  The HR Reps you have in your departments/floors/divisions will NOT handle "HR" personal type of issues, and will tell you they won't.  They are there for strategic purposes only. 
- With how much this company makes per year, annual bonuses and raises are given to the "top" performers which is based on manager discretion.  Not fair based on value you provide, time, effort, etc.  If you are not in the "boys club" you are not getting promoted, getting a raise or given a bonus.  
- Health benefits for this company lack a lot to be desired.  High deductibles, for below average coverage.

review_title: Generally Good, Execs Need to Practice What They Preach
pros:
Let me stress that one's experience at UHC is entirely dependent on the division and your direct and next-level leadership - generally up to VP level. If you land on a good team, you'll have a good experience. If you land on a bad team, best of luck to you.

My current situation is relatively good. But trust in leadership is low due to ever-changing priorities and a lack of team support. Work hours have improved, but only due to an excellent manager. 

Pros...
- Wide range of benefits
- Remote / work from home opportunities are available
- Compensation is relatively good to start
- Company culture and volunteerism is enthusiastically promoted
- Some locations have great employee extras such as onsite clinic, coffee/tea shop, convenience store, dry cleaning service, work out facilities, etc.
- Some locations are new and bright
cons:
When I first started here, I had a terrible manager, worked 60-80 hr weeks including all-nighters. 

- Benefits are difficult to navigate; Minnesota employees can't even use UHC medical insurance
- Depending on your manager/department remote work may or may not be available, or just frowned upon
- Very difficult to get promotions; at management level, annual bonuses can be good, but overall annual raises are very small
- Executive leadership doesn't practice what they preach from a culture standpoint
- Some facilities have no good employee services on site
- Some locations are old and dark

Also, the stock purchase plan is good.  One of my regrets working there was not taking advantage of the stock purchase plan sooner in my career.  The work-life balance is also great as well.  Especially during the winter, instead of battling traffic to get to work, i could work from home almost whenever i can.
cons: The one thing that I did not enjoy as much is that I never actually physically met my team members.  In fact, In the 4 years working at UnitedHealth Group, I can probably count on 2 hands the amount of people that i worked with that i actually met physically.  Your "team" is most likely scattered around the country.  When i started working at UnitedHealth Care, a lot of the project work that i was involved with was with Medicare/Medicaid products.  Unfortunately, UnitedHealth Care pulled out of the health care exchange.  That led to a lot of changes.  A lot of people got laid off.  My office eventually closed, and everyone was made to be full time telecommuters.  Also, there was a constant shifting of people.  The last calendar year that i was there, i had a total of 9 different managers, only 1 that i actually met physically.

review_title: A large company has both its benefits and drawbacks.
pros: UnitedHealth Group is a large organization that offers a variety of opportunities.  Within the company, each business unit has its own culture, so if the fit is not right in one area, there may still be opportunities elsewhere.  The company is successful at identifying employees that are strong assets to the organization and developing and promoting those individuals.  The PTO plan is on par with other organizations.  The company touts "work-life balance", however application of this ideal is applied inconsistenly throughout the organization.  After loads of negative press, Senior Leadership seems to have made a renewed focus on providing high-quality service and taking an active role in working with government to create affordable healthcare solutions for the future.
cons: Because the company has been mired in negative press for the last couple of years, there is a cynicism embedded into the corporate culture.  The large size of the organization makes it difficult to make quick decisions, so the direction of the company often seems more reactionary than proactive.  Additionally, some leaders take a micro-managing approach that can make the lives of their employees miserable.  The health benefits offerred by UnitedHealth Group are poor compared with other companies, and employees are likely to have to pay a high deductible in the spirit of "consumer driven healthcare", which is just another way of cutting costs for the employer.

cons: HR promises the world and doesn't deliver. They advertise this is the place for a career not just a job. Truth is they just want you to fill their seat quota until the Annual Enrollment Period is over and then let everyone go. Told would be paid bonus end of year, guess what - day it was due told they did not meet quotas. Told you can make a lot more than your hourly pay, guess what - it might amount to $40 per pay period (if you're lucky). Told to do what is right for he customer, guess what - yelled at if you did not make a sale on every call whether it was in the customer's best interest or not. Your schedule is never permanent and changes every week so it is almost impossible to make appointments. Ask for any time off and you are penalized.

review_title: Great work-life balance; Boring projects; Non-competitive salary
job_title: Applications Developer II in Horsham, PA
pros:
I'm an IT professional who worked on the Compas applicatioin for the Medicare & Retirement (previously known as Ovations) business segment.  So this review is mainly in regards that.  

As a whole, UHG is a great place to work.  They have flexible hours with telecommuting options.  No one's ever breathing down your back.  There's always some sort of event that involves food and employee interaction.  Great PTO from the start!  The employees are what make UHG a good place to work.  I've come to know a lot of great folks, and that was one of THE toughest parts about my departure.
cons:
The technical projects were not interesting.  Project decisions and design were mainly provided by developer leads and their direct reports, thus not allowing professional growth in the full SDLC (Software Development Life Cycle) process for mid-senior level developers.  The technology and methodologies are well dated.  Projects and simple tasks take forever to complete do to the amount of red-tape and hurdles to get through.  Seems like 50% of the development staff just want to manage.  There's very few 'true' developers.

The department as a whole is disfunctional.  They preach innovation but fail to be innovative.  You have Developers telling Functional Analysts how to and what to write in their technical documents (use cases, system requirements, so on).  Makes you wonder why even bother having FAs.  The salary is not competitive.  I basically got a 20K jump in salary after leaving!  Oh, and there's basically a "re-org" every six months.

review_title: Performance & Results are the Coin of the Realm
pros: Dynamic and fast changing environment with new roles, work and opportunities; Clear market leader with an exceptional reputation for execution; Executive Management (C-Suite) tends to make very few mistakes and conservatively positions organization against downside risks. Lots of positive improvements within its Learning & Development group; Being within the organization provides a great deal of credibility if looking to transition internally as lateral moves are encouraged;  Large percentage of women within the organization especially in middle management roles. Genuine interest in volunteerism and social responsibility.
cons: UHG is not a paternalistic organization; the expectation is to figure it out for yourself; given the size of the organization and its scope within health services and health benefits markets it can be extremely difficult to truly understand everything the organization does; UHG is also a very, very lean organization sometimes this is to its own detriment operationally. Given the weak HR function (in terms of employee relations), line managers have a lot of leeway; change & re-organizations not always well explained or the impact at the front lines not foreseen; typically more fire fighting than fire prevention; weak in regards to process documentation in non-core business functions and this has a greater than normal impact at UHG when even small personnel transitions occur; Innovation and Improvement are often trumped by immediate Performance and Results; Some alignment and silo-ing issues (areas/groups still figuring out how best to work together and present a single face to the customer/client); Most employees not thrilled about employee health benefits and costs , which tends to reflect the broader market and not a Fortune 20 organization.

review_title: Great future but a long road ahead!
pros: Great company overall and wonderful to be part of UnitedHealth Group. The company is growing and offers a strong benefits package. There are some dynamic opportunities and innovative ideas but it will be awhile before they come through. Executive Leadership is driving a culture of innovation and professionalism. UHG offers a lot of development options but not all of them have filtered down to OptumRx yet.
cons: In at least one segment of OptumRx Leadership is very reactive. The company has become experts in making things work during times of crisis. They have SO many "work arounds" and cross trained employees that they expect all employees to drop everything and do whatever is necessary. Work-life balance is not respected by Senior Management (Directors, VP). However, Executive Management (CEO, President) has great vision and plans to accomplish their goals.

pros: I can't think of anything that stands out when compared to other leading companies. if I have to think of one thing, they are so large, you can find a job in any state with them most likely.
cons:
In regards to being a Full Time Employee at United Health Group, their view of PTO it is a "grant" to the employee.

If you decide to leave the company and give notice, you lose all earned PTO that you have earned for that year,if you have not used it. How's that for true benefits?

Let's say you worked very hard all year, and have what equals to 3 weeks of vacation used ( Again you worked hard and did not take time off). You get a new job, and give your notice. You lose all that PTO, and you do not receive cash equivalent for this.

I think this is disgusting, considering UHG is largest insurer in this country with billions in revenue and they treat their employees like this.

In 2013, PTO is earned by the employee. We deserve paid time off as they is what we agreed to when hired. I have to assume not one of their 30,000 employees know this is the rule of UHG when they are hired.

You also only get 18 days off if you start in the low pay bands, other companies give you 20. Why would a company not just make it 20 which is a full 4 weeks off a year. I just don't understand the leaders of this company.

Corporate results impress Wall Street yet bonuses are barely funded to targets and 25-40 per cent of staff are "skipped" (no bonus) by mandate  to fund others.  Raises (if you are fortunate to get one) are funded at 1.5% and most senior leaders won't get them regardless of where they fall in ranges.  Stock awards have reduced greatly. job_title: Senior Quality Analyst (QA) in Savage, MN
pros:
The corporate and Optum campuses in Minnesota are nice buildings to work out of. They are very clean and have a lot of amenities.

They offer work at home opportunities - both part time and full time.

My current team is fantastic at understanding when situations happen where you might need to work from home on a non-WFH day. We're only part time WFH (2 days per week) but they give us extra days for bad weather or if something comes up (car trouble, etc).

It's a great place to start a career in health insurance.
cons:
Health insurance benefits are awful. Which is sad, because you're working for an insurance company.

Lots of younger employees, so some teams have this "high school" clique-y vibe. You're either in with the popular crowd or you're not. I see way too much goofing off happening.

There are lots of career opportunities, however, it's very difficult to move up in the ladder. I've been trying for a year and a half now and UHG hardly considers me for anything, even though I have lots of experience and I am not applying for jobs that are way out of my reach. 

You need to work a whole year in your current position before you can apply out. So if you're not happy at your job, you have to stick it out for a year if you want to stay within UHG.

pros:
Coworkers are amazing. A great effort is made to hire intelligent, dedicated, hardworking individuals with true compassion.  Compensation is competitive with local wages for unskilled labor.  Intensive training prior to working phones. 

Compassionate staff tries to mitigate stressful environment with charity drives and deep care for local community.
cons:
Every effort is made in training to convince workers that life will be great and the company cares about its workers. After training,  workers soon discover impossible to meet metrics and that the company motto of "empathy" really means "show pity". Employees are held responsible for all bad reviews by customers--even when customers leave great personal feedback but negative feedback for the company itself.  

Bonuses and raises are nearly impossible to get based of of the metric system in place. Most employees, no matter how good/experienced spend most of their time under the threat of corrective action.  So, in addition to just the regular stress of being yelled at by customers,  you are constantly worried about keeping your job. One bad customer review will cancel 30 great reviews and tank your month.

Turnover is extremely high. Company keeps sites understaffed leading to burnout, especially during busy seasons.

pros:

cons:

- As a contracted employee I wasn't required to do anything extra, but it seemed like the production environment really took a tole on people because there is usually an abundance of work 
- Friends who are actual employees always complained about not enough opportunities to advance. They have been working for UHG for three years, and I started off at the same wage that they have. It was awfully demotivating to them.

review_title: Overall its a good place to work
job_title: Network Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Start of with 4 weeks PTO;  You are not the only one doing your job - lots of people to assist with coverage.   Pay is on par with the avg
cons:
For a network engineer - its a little too SILO'd for me.   For example - as a network engineer in the datacenter, I like to unbox a new switch, rack it, stack it, cable it, configure it, and operate/maintain it.   What I just listed is done by 6 different people operating in their own SILO's.

For example, there is someone that specs out heating/cooling and the physical layout of where the switch goes, then someone else unboxes/screws it in, then someone else installs modules/plugs the data cables in, then someone else configures it and powers it on.

Also - since its a Healthcare company that operates under HIPPA rules - things are locked down so tight that its impossible to get your stuff done realistically.

Also - they use HSA for their benefit package - unless you are Grade 25 or below (Desktop Support Analyst) you cannot have a PPO.   (Network Engineers typically start at Grade 27ish)  An HSA is where you have to contribute x dollars a month into a Savings Account and you are responsible for the first 3500 - 4500 dollars of your health costs.  Full coverage kicks in after that.   So if you are a healthy jock - this works against you.   If you have a terminal condition - this is the best package for you.   After the initial deductable - 100% coverage kicks in.

pros:
working from home
i have a job
cons: has gone downhill.  lots of recent layoffs.  makes everyone nervous.  bonuses seriously downgraded over last year.  no raises ever since working here.  productivity is everything and you're reminded of it multiple times a day through "uplifting" (read, threatening) emails.  supervisors and managers very "party line" and you have a feeling a lot not being said - if they even know anything - it's hard to tell. people are afraid to ask questions because they get angry. if minimum wage really goes up to $15/hr, i might rather work at macdonalds - seriously.  probably more fun for same money.  UHG considers this position "data entry clerk."  there's a lot more to this than typing in names and addresses.  doesn't seem fair. medical benefits are basically catastrophic only.  can't afford deductible on salary.  there's lots of different depts and jobs but you have no idea what they are or what those people do or how to try to change positions within the company--even laterally.  maybe you would need to talk to people and "make friends" to find out but there's no time if you're going to make your "numbers" for the day.  they come up with "events" and "appreciation" days but again, how do you participate and get your work done?  i don't get it.  saw emails of holiday events and "winners" of contests, etc. through the day were all supervisors who aren't on our same productivity track.  glad they had fun.

job_title: Applications Development Consultant in Hartford, CT
pros: Up-to-date buildings, including nice break room; half-decent bonuses and vacation time; opportunities IF you have the right mindset and you're in the right department (see "Cons"), friendly co-workers. Definitely the overall culture is outstanding, encouraging volunteer work and making a good effort to connect workers on a personal level with coworkers and lower-level management. I recommend this company as long as you find the right position for you.
cons: Somewhat fragmented IT department; "right mindset" means you agree with upper management and has little or nothing to do with drive or talent; some departments offer good work/life balance, but some (especially within Optum) have terrible work/life balance (hope you like working nights and weekends). Opportunities for "techies" minimal; very hard to change positions because of a one-year requirement (have to stay in one job for a year before posting out). Mid-level management not particularly concerned with the well-being of their employees. Some try, some don't - and I think it's the fault of senior management. I do not recommend this company if you're just trying to get a foot in the door.

pros: Good benefits overall with the exception of Health Insurance which is costly premiums and high deductibles (but you do get a nice HSA).  Stock options are great!  It is a huge company with a lot of opportunities.  Very strong community service environment as a whole but in the smaller offices (in smaller communities) I believe they are even more community focused.  There were many good things done for the community.  Communication is good, there are a number of town halls meetings throughout the year as well as monthly office communication meetings.
cons: The smaller satellite offices (in the small communities) are somewhat cold to outsiders coming into the organization.  At times there is a lack of trust into simple technologies that will make people more efficient, instead of doing things through automation they would rather print off sheets, manually research and manually track information.  Also the smaller satellite offices have a large turnover and struggle to get good people in the door, it was constant interviewing, hiring and training.  I am sure it is a different environment in the larger offices or in the home office.  Also, there is a lack of work life balance, so you need to choose between time with your family or work (if you choose family you can expect discussions with your manager), again this is from my perspective at a smaller office in a smaller community.

review_title: All around good place to work
pros:
People make the difference.  In my years at UHG I've worked with a really great goup of people and that makes all of the difference. The work/life balance is appropriate, I've been given very generaous flexibility to work remotely as needed (especially helpful  during snow storms and when the kids are sick).  I've had numerous managers provide positive feedback for my work.  Sometimes just a note of thanks othertimes a $ bonus.   So good performance is often recognized.
Training is a priority.  Management is open to change (often driven by quality improvement initiatives).   
I've had good success with internal career advancement here.  Much of this is due to networking and reaching across groups.  It takes patience and persistance.  HR is not a key driver in this process... managers are.
disclaimer... UHG is a large companie and with all large companies there is variation.   I've heard of other areas in the organization which are not the same.  My experience is greatly influenced by immediate managers and directors. 

other positive items..  401k, ample time off.
cons: Medical benefits are so-so.  UHG often tests out new products on it's own... CDHP aka high deductible health plans are the primary offering.   So just cause they sell "Cadillac" plans to their customers, don't expect it working here.

cons:
Cons of Optum:
This may be particular to my experience working there, but the management in my area seemed a bit disorganized regarding what strategy to purse. review_title: If you liked the 50's, come here...
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Minnetonka, MN
pros:
-If you're on the right team, flexibility is amazing.

cons:
-Technology is an absolute joke
-If you are a career admin, avoid this place. There are only two true levels of admin, and no actual path which is not what recruiting will tell you. The role of admin isn't taken seriously at all here.

-They never look for improvement. We're always running a thousand miles an hour, but if you ask "why?" or "let's pause and see what could change," it's not appreciated nor accepted. 
-No actual career discussions. Leaders don't lead or inspire, they're just creating work.
-Culture is very uninspiring.

review_title: Good place to work, but there is high turnover
job_title: Software Engineer in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: I really liked the people I worked with, for the most part. The company is making pushes to reduce tech debt and explore exciting new frameworks and design patterns. This leads to exciting and challenging work full of learning opportunities. The end of year bonuses are pretty decent when the company performs, and the employee stock purchase program is a great way to invest in the company you work for while maintaining generally fantastic returns. The healthcare plans are, well, affordable and high quality, given that Optum is a UnitedHealth Group company.
cons: Talented people leave. Management seems unable or unwilling to raise and promote talented employees from within. The turnover for the teams that were around me was really high, and the people I know who left generally left for large promotions. There is also a push company-wide to cut costs. Unfortunately, this means more offshoring. Many of the offshore resources I worked with, while great people, simply didn’t have knowledge of newer frameworks or design patterns. In my teams, this really hurt output.

review_title: Messages from top don’t match life in the trenches
pros:
Work with great people
Talented and dedicated co workers 
Work is endless so never bored
Execs are trying to course correct culture
cons:
With the current economic picture for the company and the country, 2% or lower raises just don’t cut it. Bonus program requires managers to cut 1/3 of the workers despite quality of performance on team. Not a fluke. Seen it handled this way for years and managers talk about it openly. 
Work is endless. OT is endless. 
If your VP isn’t a people person you will never feel the message delivered at the top in your team.

review_title: Rewards for pushing claims for bonuses.
job_title: Claims Representative in International Falls, MN
pros: Benefits , start pay , flex time. Work anywhere . Casual dress , local manager works with you.
cons:
Overall good. Pay starts off competitive but raises are only 3.5 percent if you get 5/5 for your review. 
Bonuses work out well if your perfect. One error can take away $150.00 for that month. No give on if you get a error and are certified, that hits hard as if the last three months didn’t matter. This new rewards program has made many coworkers skip hard claims so they keep great quality and keep production up. This makes others pick up all the claims people don’t want to do and their metics suffer . United Healthcare knows this happens it doesn’t care enough to stop it. Team work suffers when you can see others skipping and they lie about it. They are all thinking for themselves, more money regardless who they have to backstab. The rewards system favors those that do the most claims perfectly. If you have great quality and low production you don’t get any reward for the bonuses. 
 
Also there are some people that work so hard and only get 4/5 for reviews. This is discouraging for moving forward, makes them think they can’t get a 5/5 rating even if they have perfect quality.

review_title: Great company in the US, lousy to work for outside of the US.
pros: United is a good name to have on your CV but the lack of any real commitment to training and development for staff outside of the US is very evident. Generally most people are fairly friendly but there's no real company spirit as such - it's the kind of company where you know that most of your colleagues would rather be working somewhere else.
cons: United is first and foremost an American company. This manifests in the lack of any effort to retain and develop staff or managers outside of the States. Managers in the US are on average, not terribly world wise with the result that they tend to wade in and tell international staff what's what despite having little or no insight or experience themselves. The training and development is amongst the worst of any company I've worked for - this seems to stem from a Human Capital function that would be better described as a personnel function given that they have no clear strategy for development of human capital. The appraisal system is a complete lottery and can be abused by senior managers to punish staff with low / no pay rises even when it's clear they have performed. Lastly, whilst some managers are hard working, committed and capable, some appear to have been promoted largely on their ability to slate everyone else at every opportunity.

job_title: Medical Director CCR in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Great salary, work from home,  enjoy work 
Wonderful team of medical directors.  Great teamwork among peers, employee stock purchase program .
cons:
This is a job not a career. Many cannot wait to retire. There is no culture. Unless the culture is work until you drop dead! As a group, we feel unappreciated and unrecognized. The company gets you in on the great salary and then nicked and dimes. You work very hard for this salary often working on weekends and holidays or putting in 12 hours starring into a computer screen. 
This past year the company showed outstanding earrings, the stock is through the roof, and the company was given a huge corporate tax break.
I was hopeful that the company would recognize us as part of their prosperity similar to what ATT and Apple did with their employees. Instead, many had their bonuses cut. We work very hard at CCR often ignoring our own needs, our health, and the needs of our families. There is no work / life balance. Not if you do the job right. We feel disregarded and very used. Upper management is self serving, narcissistic, and toxic, I think UHC needs to drain the swamp!

pros:
- Opportunity for advancement - if you understand that this is up to you and not your manager. I have moved up 5 grades in 5 years. Yes, there are definitely some terrible "managers" who do their best to hold you back, but there are also some amazing "leaders" who want to see you succeed. 
- Incoming salary - once you're in the company, the raises are just ok. The best way to get more money is to go for a promotion. It is a global organization, so you are not required to stay within the same department. You can branch out.
- The Idea of the Core Values
cons:
- Not enough retraining for managers - too many managers and not enough leaders
- Healthcare benefits are terrible (it's tough listening to some of the complaints of some of the people that report to me indirectly - hourly employees have a hard time with their out of pocket healthcare costs)
- Pay increases

review_title: Neutral review for a growing company with ups and downs.
pros: The company had many job openings all over the country which helps with career advancement.  They promote telecommuting in some area.  They have a generous employee stock purchase program which is their number one employee benefit in my opinion.  UHC seems very liberal with the career advancement paths.  You are encouraged to apply for jobs throughout the company.  They have many different business segments that offer just about every type of job imaginable.  They have a very generous Paid Time Off program too.  It's not a micro-management environment which I think would be a plus for most people.  The company has had some rough times lately but once it gets most of the big acquisitions properly aligned the company will take off once again and be a corporate giant.
cons: The company has grown too fast and is too large.  You are just a number as opposed to a person.  The company has so many offices in so many areas that it's just too large to properly manage all areas with the current structure.  I think there have been a lot of poor decisions made in the past few years.  The decisions seem to have been made too hastily without proper due diligence.  It's hard to be organized in an efficient way when you are so large.  The health care benefits offered to employees are subpar compared to other companies.  This seems like an obvious area of improvement considering they're in the health care industry.

pros: Serving clients with diverse needs in a rural area. Working with some very compassionate and driven team members.  Company provided uniforms.
cons: Lack of leadership, organization, and non-competitive salary.  Higher than average staff turnover rate.  Using outdated McKesson documentaion software.  Lack of resources for the patients. Normally,  a high quality hospice home care company offers the patient,  toward the very end of life, a continuous nurse in attendance- this office did not. On call nurse expected to drive exceptionally long distances, sometimes causing the next patient in need to wait an inordinate amount of time. Backup call nurse often complained about having to visit a patient.  Overall,  high turnover rate including management and director and lack of leadership along with arbitrary implementation of policy and procedures.

review_title: An incredibly self serving, wealthy company
job_title: RN Field Nurse in Greensboro, NC
pros: Work from home (although they work you to death). Another "pro", I got out and now have the job of my dreams. Very happy to be outta the snake pit
cons: Poor pay, dishonest, lacks integrity. I exceeded the required metrics EVERY MONTH, had 100% on all audits with the exception of 2 months (and those months were still exceeding the minimum metric) the entire 3 1/2 years I worked there and received a maximum of 1.039% raise. No, not a typo! Each monthly leadership call entailed bragging about how much money we were making (I worked for MEDICARE!!) while at the same time having to console crying members because they could not afford their $300+ premiums. That's when my conscience got to me. As a nurse, I felt like a traitor working for them and I will always feel that way. Also--I worked 50-60 hours per week and didn't get paid for 15,000 miles of mileage. Again, not a typo. I would not recommend this company to ANY NURSE. Oh and by the way, they replaced the field nurses with community health workers (no medical training--apparently UHC feels they are also above the law).

pros:

Free coffee

Highly political environment; merit is undervalued - politics overvalued

job_title: Prefer Not To Say in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I worked in two segments of UHG for a total of seven years and each year received excellent reviews and a performance bonus. Had some excellent, experienced, dedicated colleagues.
cons: United has earned its nickname of The Evil Empire. In my last stint at UHC, I reported to a newly-hired director who was incompetent but covered her inexperience by blaming, demeaning and chastising her team. After several incidents of bullying and abuse from her, I reported her to HR. BIG MISTAKE. I was naïve and considered my tenure and excellent work history to be in my favor, and was assured that UHG's non-retaliation policy would afford me protection. One week after filing a formal grievance against my director with HR, and one month after my seventh excellent performance review, I was put on a Corrective Action Plan (CAP). The CAP was fabricated evidence from the prior year of my performance flaws; none of which were accurate, (had they been, they would have been in my performance review). In addition, my director became even more hostile and aggressive toward me, making my work life even more miserable than before. There was nothing I could do but resign.
